forecast.rationale:
My forecast is primarily based on the strong statistical principle of regression to the mean. The research shows that as of mid-May 2025, Aaron Judge has a batting average over .400 (e.g., .414 on May 17), a rare accomplishment for this point in the season. While this makes a 'Yes' outcome plausible, maintaining such a high average is historically difficult. The 'tyranny of the denominator' in batting averages means that as the season progresses, it becomes harder to maintain an outlier figure. Even over a short 13-day period, a few hitless games can significantly lower an average, as evidenced by a recent 0-for-5 performance mentioned in the report.

My probability is not higher than 35% because historical precedent and statistical likelihood weigh heavily against any player maintaining a .400 average. Judge is performing far above his career norms, and it is statistically more likely that his performance will cool down and regress toward his baseline, even if that baseline remains exceptional. Pitchers will also continue to adjust their strategies against him.

However, the probability is not lower because Judge is currently exceeding the .400 threshold, giving him a small cushion. The remaining timeframe is short—roughly 12-13 games—which increases the chance that a hot streak can be sustained compared to a longer period. He doesn't need to get hot to reach .400; he just needs to stay hot to maintain it.

I would increase my forecast if Judge posts several multi-hit games in the coming week, expanding his cushion above .400. Conversely, I would decrease my forecast significantly if he has another 0-for-4 or 0-for-5 game in the near future or sustains any minor injury.
